data.title: Indian shares breathe a sigh of relief on US tariffs pause
data.description:
Indian shares rose on Tuesday, tracking the gains in other Asian markets, after the U.S. paused its planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico, easing concerns over a potential worldwide trade war.

The Nifty 50 had risen by 0.82% to 23,553 points as of 10:12 a.m. IST, while the BSE Sensex had gained 0.88% to 77,858.88.

U.S. President Donald Trump suspended his threat of steep tariffs on Mexico and Canada on Monday, agreeing to a 30-day pause in return for some concessions. Tariffs on China, however, are due to take effect within hours.

"Sentiment has turned positive after Trump delayed the imposition of tariffs on Canada and Mexico," said Abhishek Goenka, the founder and chief executive of IFA Global.

The Nifty started February on a weak note after a mixed federal budget and the trade war fears, threatening to extend a four-month losing streak. That, however, has made stock prices relatively cheaper.

"With the recent correction, valuations in the large-cap space now seem reasonable, prompting investor interest," Goenka said.

On the day, 12 of the 13 major domestic sectors advanced.

The metal index rose 2% on the day. It lost 3% in the prior two sessions due to the U.S. dollar's strength on plans for U.S. tariffs.

Rate-sensitive auto and realty stocks were 1% higher, continuing to benefit from expectations of higher spending after an income tax cut in the budget and on hopes of an interest rate cut later this week.

Oil & Natural Gas Corp rose 2.4% after brokerages highlighted the scope for better earnings due to robust production growth. ONGC had shed 5% in two sessions after missing its December-quarter profit estimates.

Divi's Laboratories jumped 5.5%, taking its gains to 10% over two sessions after beating third-quarter profit estimates.

data.title: EMEA Morning Briefing: Stock Futures Rise After U.S. Delays Mexico, Canada Tariffs
data.description:
MARKET WRAPS

Watch For:

Trading updates from UBS, BNP Paribas, Intesa Sanpaolo, Diageo, Infineon Technologies, Vodafone Group, Publicis

Opening Call:

European and U.S. stock futures gained alongside advances by Asian benchmarks following a delay to U.S. tariffs on Canada and Mexico. The dollar fell; Treasury yields edged higher; while oil and gold futures fell.

Equities:

Stock futures were higher early Tuesday, while markets across Asia staged a relief rally as risk sentiment improved after President Trump and the leaders of Mexico and Canada reached a deal to put tariffs on hold for a month.

Meanwhile, China hopes to negotiate over the 10% extra being imposed on its exports to the U.S. Beijing is readying an opening bid to try to head off greater tariff increases and technology restrictions.

The on-again, off-again tariffs briefly hit the market on Monday, before fear evaporated. What it shows: Investors are convinced he will use tariffs to extract concessions on other issues, rather than, as he keeps saying, to raise money and force companies to relocate to America.

Forex:

The U.S. dollar is likely to maintain its safe-haven status in 1H, DBS's Philip Wee said. Trade uncertainties loom despite the U.S. delaying tariffs on Canada and Mexico, the senior forex strategist said, adding there's potential volatility in markets from Trump's unpredictability.

Meanwhile, Trump has given notice that the European Union is next in line for U.S. tariffs, Wee noted. Also, there was no 30-day reprieve for the additional 10% tariff on Chinese imports, with markets awaiting responses from Chinese President Xi, Wee said.

Bonds:

The corporate-debt market has so far shrugged off Trump's tariff announcements. After a brief disruption in debt issuance, companies of varying credit quality are expected to resume debt sales Tuesday, bankers and analysts say.

"After monitoring how things are going, it feels like the tone is a lot better," said Meghan Robson, head of U.S. credit strategy for BNP Paribas.

"As long as we're on a Fed pause, we think credit can do well," said Robson. "When you get rate hikes, we'd start to be more concerned about fundamentals, but we think we're still a ways away from that."

Energy:

Volatility remains high in crude oil markets as the threat of U.S. tariffs continues to loom, ANZ said. Trump's calls for OPEC to lower prices were meanwhile ignored, as the group decided not to make any changes to its existing oil production plans, ANZ added. The OPEC+ alliance is likely awaiting more clarity on other Trump policies, ANZ said.

Metals:

Despite the U.S. deal to delay tariffs on Canada and Mexico, "uncertainty over trade and tariffs continues to buoy gold prices," ING said.

The bank said the precious metal had risen to a new all-time high after Trump's initial imposition of tariffs as investors sought safe havens. ING added that dollar strength has offset some strength in gold overnight.

-

Copper gained in Asian trade. Uncertainty over tariffs is likely to keep volatility high in commodity markets, ANZ said. Base metals had been under pressure recently due to demand concerns stemming from the impending trade war, it said.

TODAY'S TOP HEADLINES

U.S. Pauses Tariffs on Mexico, Canada. China Levies Are Still Happening-for Now.

President Donald Trump is pausing plans for 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada after separate meetings with the leaders of both nations.

Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a social media post on Monday afternoon that the threatened tariffs had been paused for "at least" 30 days.

Bitcoin rebounds after Trump pauses Mexico, Canada tariffs. Here's why the crypto reacts to tariffs.

Bitcoin rebounded to above $100,000 by Monday evening, after President Donald Trump said he would pause imposing tariffs on Mexico and Canada.

Bitcoin BTCUSD, the largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization, experienced a weekend selloff, falling to as low as $91,229 early Monday, its lowest level since Jan. 13, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

A U.S.-EU Trade War Would Threaten World's Richest Economic Relationship

BRUSSELS-European leaders, bracing for a fight with President Trump over the world's most valuable trading relationship, said they are ready to strike back but prefer cooperation.

Trump over the weekend announced punishing tariffs on Canada and Mexico and made clear that U.S. allies across the Atlantic were high on his target list. He later agreed to pause tariffs on Canada and Mexico for one month.

Tariffs Will Be Especially Bad for Europe. What They Mean for European Stocks.

With friendly trade partners like these, who needs enemies? That is what European countries must be thinking as President Donald Trump prepares to target them with his next round of taxes on imported goods.

After unveiling 25% levies on goods from Canada and Mexico, as well as an additional 10% tax on Chinese products, Trump said Sunday that he would soon move on to Europe.

Apple escaped tariffs last time. This time, it may have to raise prices.

Apple Inc. was one of the luckier consumer-electronics companies when it got exemptions from the tariffs imposed by the first Trump administration on many goods made in China.

But this time, it might not be quite as fortunate.

Nvidia's stock falls as these two questions dog investors

Nvidia Corp.'s stock fell Monday as investors weighed the potential for tariffs to impact chip companies and continued to assess the fallout from DeepSeek.

Shares of Nvidia NVDA slid 2.8% to rank among the worst performers in the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX. The stock pared losses after President Donald Trump said he had agreed to pause the Mexico tariffs for a month. A similar deal to delay tariffs on Canada came later in the day. China still faces 10% tariffs starting at midnight.

Write to singaporeeditors@dowjones.com

Expected Major Events for Tuesday

01:01/IRL: Jan Ireland Manufacturing PMI

07:00/ROM: Dec PPI

08:00/SPN: Jan Unemployment

16:00/DEN: Jan Foreign Exchange & Liquidity

All times in GMT. Powered by Onclusive and Dow Jones.

Write to us at newsletters@dowjones.com

We offer an enhanced version of this briefing that is optimized for viewing on mobile devices and sent directly to your email inbox. If you would like to sign up, please go to https://newsplus.wsj.com/subscriptions.

This article is a text version of a Wall Street Journal newsletter published earlier today.

data.title: Another catch your breath session in Europe today
data.description:
At the end of it all, the tariff can gets kicked down the road. Trump pushed the 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico to a month from now, allowing for trade negotiations to take place in the meantime. His team might be pushing the narrative that with Canada, it's a fentanyl issue. However, most of his disdain towards Canada seems to be on trade. So, go figure.

As things stand, all there's left is that 10% tariffs on China - at least in this opening salvo. But Trump did say that there would be talks with Xi "probably in the next 24 hours". So, we'll see.

But for now at least, markets can look to catch their breath. The tariff threats are no doubt still in the picture but it also shows how Trump loves to play out his political agenda. Go big and loud in the opening gambit before trying to extract concessions after. And when a deal gets struck, it'll be "the best deal in history for the US". Sounds familiar, eh?

The dollar is seeing a little bounce back on the day but not after having seen gains evaporate in trading yesterday. The greenback opened with a gap higher across the board but as Trump relented on tariffs, that gap higher was erased. A look at USD/CAD:

USD/CAD hourly chart

As Trump calls it a day and heads to bed, markets will be able to catch a breather in European trading today. That's somewhat similar to yesterday. The only difference is that broader markets will surely feel better about the current position as opposed to the "all hell is about to break loose" possibility yesterday.

As such, risk trades might find some incentive to push higher but it's still quite a tricky landscape.

With Canada and Mexico now joining the negotiating table, Trump will look to the EU and China next. And those are likely to be tougher propositions to muster.

His erratic nature means that you never know when he's going to start to reignite tariff threats on that front. And it will keep market players more guarded than they were at the start of the year at least.

data.title: KEC International Posts Surge in Fiscal Q3 Consolidated Net Profit
data.description:
KEC International's consolidated net profit jumped to 1.30 billion Indian rupees in the fiscal third quarter from 968.7 million rupees a year ago, according to a Monday filing with the Indian exchanges by the infrastructure services provider.

Earnings per share during the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, climbed to 4.87 rupees from 3.77 rupees of the year-ago period.

Revenue from operations in fiscal Q3 also increased to 53.5 billion rupees from 50.1 billion rupees a year earlier.

data.title: HK-listed Chinese stocks surge on AI, EV rally as Trump tariffs loom
data.description:
Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong surged on Tuesday as investors loaded up on AI and EV shares, despite looming U.S. tariffs on China.

U.S. President Trump's 10% levy on Chinese goods is due to go into effect at 1:01 pm in Beijing (0501 GMT), but investors hope Trump's last-minute decision to suspend imminent tariffs on Canada and Mexico may signal there is room to negotiate.

Trump's press secretary said the president will speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping in the next couple of days.

"With Trump delaying tariffs on Canada and Mexico, will there be negotiations before further escalation on China as well? The market thinks there could still be room for talks," Jason Chan, senior investment strategist at Bank of East Asia.

The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index jumped 2.6% at midday trading break to a three-month high, while Hang Seng Tech Index surged 3.9%. The benchmark Hang Seng index added 2%.

AI-related stocks led the rally as investors continued to pile up wagers on home-grown firms after startup DeepSeek released a large language model at a cheap cost.

China's top chipmaker SMIC surged as much as 9% to a record high, and peer Hua Hong Semiconductor advanced 8.7%.

The EV sector also lifted the market, with carmaker XPeng jumping 12.6% after the company said it delivered a nearly three-fold increase in smart EVs in January year-on-year.

Financial markets in mainland China will reopen on Wednesday after the long Lunar New Year holiday, and are poised to play catch-up with global markets, he added.

China's benchmark blue chip index fell 3% in January before the holiday, surrendering nearly half of September's 40% rally.

The markets may look through the political noise to focus on China’s responses to U.S. tariffs and the upcoming National People's Congress (NPC) meeting in the next few weeks, analysts at Citi said in a note.

Capital Economics said the additional 10% tariff that Donald Trump has applied on Chinese goods will have a relatively modest impact on China’s economy, especially if the PBOC allows the yuan to adjust, but predicted the trade war with the U.S. will be protracted.

data.title: Market Chatter: London Court Approves Sino-Ocean's $6 Billion Debt Restructuring Plan
data.description:
London's High Court greenlit Chinese property developer Sino-Ocean Group's plan to restructure $6 billion of offshore debt, overriding objections from creditor Long Corridor, Reuters reported Monday.

Sino-Ocean Group is navigating a dual restructuring process in London and Hong Kong amid China's property sector crisis, according to the report.

Opposition came from creditor Long Corridor, which claims the move unfairly favored shareholders, including state-owned China Life and Dajia Insurance Group, which each hold a roughly a 30% stake, Reuters wrote. Meanwhile, Sino-Ocean argued maintaining at least 15% ownership for these entities was vital to its status as a state-owned enterprise and its survival in China's property market.

In his ruling, Judge Nicholas Thompsell said retaining these stakes "increases the value of the plan" for all creditors, according to the report.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: Wellnex Life Secures Regulatory Approval for Paracetamol Plus Caffeine Soft Gel; Shares Up 3%
data.description:
Wellnex Life received market authorization from Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration for its new liquid paracetamol plus caffeine soft gel, the company said in a Tuesday Australian bourse filing.

The product will provide opportunities to use it in the company's own brands as well as opportunities to license it to third parties, the filing added.

Company shares rose past 3% in recent Tuesday trade.

data.title: IXOPAY Appoints Yasser Abou-Nasr as SVP of Product to Drive Execution and Scale
data.description:
Seasoned Fintech Leader Joins IXOPAY to Advance Product Innovation and Drive Scalable Growth in Payment Orchestration.

LEHI, UT / ACCESS Newswire / February 4, 2025 / IXOPAY, a leading enterprise payment orchestration platform, announced the appointment of Yasser Abou-Nasr as SVP of Product. With over 16 years of senior product leadership in payments and fintech, Yasser joins IXOPAY to execute the company's strategic vision and scale its product offerings to meet the growing demand for seamless and secure payment solutions.

Yasser brings a proven track record of driving product execution at scale, combined with deep expertise in product management, operational transformation, and the development of B2B SaaS platforms. His leadership will be instrumental in advancing IXOPAY's enterprise payment orchestration platform, enabling businesses worldwide to simplify, secure, and optimize their payment systems through scalable and flexible solutions.

"Yasser's ability to execute and scale complex product strategies aligns perfectly with IXOPAY's mission to lead the global payment orchestration market," said Brady Harris, CEO of IXOPAY. "With his extensive experience in the payments ecosystem and a visionary approach to product innovation, Yasser will ensure our solutions deliver exceptional value to our customers while accelerating IXOPAY's growth trajectory."

Yasser's impressive career spans key leadership roles, including Senior Vice President of Product at Dwolla, where he successfully restructured the product organization and drove strategic execution, and Vice President of Payments Strategy and Operations at Vesta, where he oversaw the global expansion of payment acceptance and optimization initiatives.

"I am thrilled to join IXOPAY, a company that is reshaping the global payments landscape," said Yasser Abou-Nasr. "As businesses increasingly embrace multiprocessor strategies, IXOPAY's enterprise-grade platform offers unparalleled flexibility and innovation. I look forward to scaling our product offerings and delivering next-generation payment solutions to our customers worldwide."

About IXOPAY

IXOPAY is a leading provider of enterprise-grade payment orchestration, enabling businesses to simplify, secure, and scale their payment systems. In 2024, IXOPAY orchestrated over $35 billion in transactions for customers from over 30 countries. With a fully integrated platform, tokenization, and flexible payment optimization modules, IXOPAY empowers enterprises to manage payments seamlessly across multiple providers. Learn more at www.ixopay.com.

Contact: Mills Forni, Verdis, mills@verdis.xyz

SOURCE: IXOPAY

View the original press release on ACCESS Newswire

data.title: New Talisman Welcomes Inclusion of Gold in NZ Government's Critical Minerals List; Shares Rise 6%
data.description:
New Talisman Gold Mines said the inclusion of gold in the New Zealand government's critical minerals list will provide the company a "clear pathway" towards full mining, according to a Monday filing with the New Zealand bourse.

As previously announced, the mining company plans to re-apply through the Fast Track Authorization Bill for full mining consent for the historic Talisman mine and Rahu Minerals Exploration tenement, the filing said.

It said it is on track to begin production in the first quarter of 2025, per the filing.

New Talisman's shares climbed past 6% at market close on Tuesday.

Here's how much gas could cost you if Trump's threatened tariffs go through

data.title: OpenAI to Jointly Develop AI Products With South Korean Tech Giant Kakao
data.description:
By Kimberley Kao

ChatGPT creator OpenAI and South Korean mobile internet giant Kakao plan to jointly develop artificial-intelligence products for the local market.

The companies said Tuesday that they plan to form a strategic partnership, under which Kakao will integrate OpenAI's technology for its products and services, including its widely used messaging app Kakao Talk, tailored to local users.

Kakao said it will also deploy ChatGPT Enterprise, the version of ChatGPT aimed at large companies for business use, for its employees, and use OpenAI models to power its AI communication service Kanana, which Kakao describes as a "user-friendly AI mate that delivers personalized, context-aware responses."

"We're excited to bring advanced AI to Kakao's millions of users and work together to integrate our technology into services that transform how Kakao's users communicate and connect," OpenAI Chief Executive Sam Altman said in a statement.

Kakao CEO Chung Shin-a said the collaboration will help the South Korean company advance its AI efforts.

The announcement was made at a joint press conference in Seoul on the back of Altman's visit to the country. Local media outlet Yonhap News Agency reported that he has met with SK Group Chairman Chey Tae-won, who was accompanied by SK Hynix CEO Kwak Noh-jung, to discuss possible collaborations in AI.

Write to Kimberley Kao at kimberley.kao@wsj.com

data.title: PointsBet Lowers Fiscal Year 2025 Guidance on Weaker Results in Australia and Canada, Jarden Research Says
data.description:
PointsBet Holdings has downgraded its full fiscal year revenue and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) guidance after weaker-than-expected results in Australia and Canada, falling short of analyst forecasts, according to a Jan. 31 note by Jarden Research.

The company now expects full fiscal year EBITDA of AU$11 million to AU$14 million from the previous AU$11 million to AU$16 million, while revenue is forecasted to be between AU$260 million to AU$270 million, reduced from AU$280 million to AU$290 million, Jarden said.

The company reported fiscal-first half Australian turnover of AU$1.15 billion, down 23% year-on-year and below the analyst's estimate of $1.5 billion, driven by a shift from lower-margin clients, Jarden added.

PointsBet's fiscal first-half net win for Australia was AU$117 million, up 4% year-on-year but below the AU$133 million estimate, the broker noted.

Meanwhile, performance in Canada also missed expectations. PointsBet's net win in Canada was AU$18.1 million, missing the AU$24.9 million estimate by 27%, due to unfavorable NFL and iGaming results.

Despite setbacks, the gaming firm reported a modest AU$500,000 operating cash inflow for the fiscal first half ended Dec. 30, beating Jarden's AU$600,000 outflow, and expects positive net cash flows in the second half of the fiscal year.

Jarden Research has a buy rating and AU$1 price target on PointsBet Holdings.

Shares of the company fell 2% in recent Tuesday trade.

data.title: Sarytogan Graphite Identifies Copper Anomalies at Kazakhstan Project; Shares Rise 3%
data.description:
Sarytogan Graphite said an exploration review at the Baynazar copper exploration project in Kazakhstan identified three new anomalies at the Aminbay target, according to a Tuesday Australian bourse filing.

The company identified metal zonation and aeromagnetic features consistent with the possible presence of porphyry, the filing said. The review also confirmed previous results at the Ilken target.

Soil sampling will be infilled across the anomalies identified and extended ahead of planning drilling at these targets, according to the firm's managing director, Sean Gregory.

The firm's shares rose past 3% in recent trading on Tuesday.

data.title: Hong Kong’s SFC proposes expanding crypto regulatory staff in new fiscal budget
data.description:
Hong Kong’s securities watchdog has proposed adding headcounts for cryptocurrency-specific staff as the region continues its drive to become a crypto hub.

In a budget plan for the financial year 2025 to 2026, the Securities and Futures Commission proposed 15 new headcounts, with eight dedicated to “enhancing the staffing support for virtual asset regulatory regimes, market surveillance, and enforcement investigations.”

The SFC presented the budget on Monday at a Legislative Council meeting. The regulator estimated that its recurrent expenditure for the next fiscal year—starting April 1, 2025—would be HK$2.59 billion ($332.4 million), an increase of 7.2% from the forecast expenditure for 2024-25.

Much of the budget increase stems from a rise in staff costs by HK$130.5 million ($16.7 million), which includes an average salary hike of about 2.1%. The SFC noted that it froze its headcount in three out of the five financial years since 2020-21.

The SFC pointed out in a separate document on Monday that it has deployed staff with experience in licensing and supervision to cope with crypto-related regulatory work. However, it could only conduct on-site inspections of some 200 licensed corporations in 2023, which “fell short of the target of 300.” 

Hong Kong has opened its doors to crypto firms. In June 2023, it officially launched a crypto licensing regime for “virtual asset trading platforms” (VATPs), allowing licensed exchanges to offer retail trading services. The government’s proposed stablecoin bill is also progressing through the Legislative Council.

In December, the SFC said it has worked to speed up the VATP licensing process. “We have been proactively engaging with VATPs’ senior management and ultimate controllers, which helps drive home our expected regulatory standards and expedite our licensing process for VATPs,” Eric Yip, the SFC’s Executive Director of Intermediaries, said in a December statement.

Last month, the SFC approved licenses for two additional crypto trading platforms — PantherTrade and YAX, according to the regulator’s website. This brought the total number of licensed platforms to nine, including OSL and HashKey.

Disclaimer: The Block is an independent media outlet that delivers news, research, and data. As of November 2023, Foresight Ventures is a majority investor of The Block. Foresight Ventures invests in other companies in the crypto space. Crypto exchange Bitget is an anchor LP for Foresight Ventures. The Block continues to operate independently to deliver objective, impactful, and timely information about the crypto industry. Here are our current financial disclosures.

data.title: Market Chatter: China's Currency May Further Weaken Amid Trade Tensions With US
data.description:
Analysts believe the China's renminbi may further weaken if US President Donald Trump's new tariffs become effective, Bloomberg reported Tuesday.

Economists at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group, along with those at Malayan Banking, said People's Bank of China may set the currency's fixing at 7.2 yuan per dollar. Goldman Sachs Group forecasted a 7.3 yuan per dollar fixing, the report said.

The renminbi reached its lowest since October 2022 to as much as 0.7% to 7.3734 yuan per dollar on Monday after Trump announced a 10% duty on China, which is lower than the 60% levy previously planned, the media outlet said.

China's central bank may announce its fixing limit plans on Wednesday when the mainland's markets resume after the Chinese New Year holiday, the report said.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: LIC Housing Finance Likely to Continue Delivering Healthy Asset Quality — Market Talk
data.description: LIC Housing Finance is likely to continue delivering healthy asset quality, Nomura analysts say in a research report. Its gross and net non-performing assets dropped by 152 bps and 32 bps, respectively, in 3Q FY 2025, and it posted a credit cost of negative 0.1% driven by provision write-backs, the analysts note. Thanks to further resolutions of such assets, the Indian housing finance company's credit costs are expected to remain contained at around 35 bps over FY 2026-2027, the analysts estimate. Nomura raises the stock's target price to INR 735.00 from INR 700.00, maintaining an unchanged buy rating. Shares are 2.3% higher at INR 570.70. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

data.title: HSBC Buys Back Another 3.4 Million Shares in Hong Kong
data.description:
HSBC Holdings bought back 3,397,000 shares in Hong Kong on Monday at a weighted average price of HK$79.85 per share, according to a Tuesday filing with the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

Since the current buy-back program has started, the British lender has repurchased 301,116,739 shares for about $2.84 billion.

data.title: Vinci Consortium Wins EUR183 Million River Access Contract in France
data.description:
A Vinci consortium won a contract worth 183 million euros to build a river link to Port 2000 in Le Havre in Normandy, France.

The project, named La Chatière, will deliver a 1.8-kilometer river channel directly connecting Port 2000 and the Seine river basin, according to a Monday release from the construction, energy and concessions company. The project is scheduled to commence operations in 2027.

Vinci Construction holds a 62% stake in the consortium, while Belgium's Deme holds 38%. Vinci also owns a 12.1% stake in Deme.

data.title: Mitrajaya Repurchases More Shares
data.description:
Mitrajaya Holdings bought back 241,000 shares on Monday for 78,897 ringgit, according to a same-day bourse disclosure.

The shares were purchased at 0.325 ringgit apiece, the Malaysian construction company said.

data.title: PMI: Saudi Arabia's Non-oil Private Sector Growth Hits 10-Year High in January
data.description:
Business activity growth in Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector strengthened significantly in January 2025 due to the fastest increase in total new orders since June 2011 and the strongest year-ahead outlook in 10 months, the Riyad Bank and S&P Global said Tuesday.

The Riyad Bank Saudi Arabia PMI climbed to 60.5 from 58.4 in December 2024, reflecting the highest reading since September 2014.

data.title: Kasikornbank Target Price Lowered to THB187.00 From THB188.00 by CGS International >KBANK.TH
Australia's Astute Metals jumps on lithium find at US project
data.description:
** Astute Metals soars 18.8% to A$0.038, highest since Jan. 20

** Stock rose as much as 21.9% to A$0.039 earlier in the day, marking the biggest intraday gain since Jan. 20

** Diversified explorer says it has identified new zone of lithium bearing clay-rich rocks at its Red Mountain Lithium Project in Nevada, USA

** Adds, "Identification of new high-grade lithium-bearing unit increases project's potential"

** Around 784,720 shares traded, 2.3x the 30-day avg

** ASE up 35.7% YTD

data.title: BH Global Forms New Subsidiary
data.description:
Marine electrical products supplier BH Global established a wholly-owned subsidiary, namely, Infravision Technology, according to a filing with the Singapore Exchange on Monday.

The new company has an initial issued and paid up capital of SG$100 comprising 100 shares and is involved in the manufacturing and repairing of engineering and scientific instruments.

data.title: Power Root Repurchases More Shares
data.description:
Power Root on Tuesday bought back 104,200 shares for 152,594 ringgit, according to a same-day bourse disclosure.

The shares were repurchased at between 1.460 ringgit and 1.500 ringgit apiece, the beverage company said.
